Legal_Issue: Did the Visa Officer err in refusing Mr. Sahota's application for permanent residence as a self-employed person?
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Sahota had over 30 years of farming experience but lacked knowledge of Canadian farming practices, specifics about his proposed farm, crops, geography, and business plan realism.
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility as a self-employed person
Credibility_Factor: Limited understanding of Canadian farming and business plan details affected credibility of intent and ability
Legal_Rule: A 'self-employed person' must have relevant experience, intention, and ability to contribute economically to Canada.
Procedural_Issue: Whether the Visa Officerâ€™s refusal was legally justified under immigration regulations
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Visa Officer in assessing eligibility under self-employed category
Key_Evidence_Considered: Farming experience, knowledge of Canadian agriculture, proposed business plan, understanding of geography and crop selection
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged refusal of permanent residence application
Defendant_Response: Visa Officer found intentions and abilities insufficient based on incomplete understanding and unrealistic plan
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application materials, officer's assessment
Legal_Provision: Section related to self-employed persons under IRPR
Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations - Self-Employed Persons
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet criteria for self-employed person class
Governing_Rule: Self-employed person must intend and be able to make significant contribution to specified economic activity
